Comment: The relevant section and some doom and glooming for those curious about the argument being (not) made.   > we have tools in America that many other failed democracies lacked, like an independent judiciary that has ruled against Trump 70 times since he swore his oath.    The courts have shown themselves not to be the same sort of spineless sycophants that Congress has turned out to be. However they have very little real power or authority in the Machiavellian sense. They have no following, so supporters, no sworn soldiers, and no enforcement mechanism that isn't dependent on the good will of people *who have no obligation to them*. Their power (outside the pretty words in a 200 year old parchment) is derived entirely from the deference of Congress and the executive. Furthermore the recent actions of the supreme court reek of individuals attempting to secure their status in the "after".   >We have a free press that Trump loathes but can’t stop.    Seeing as a member of that press wrote this the only thing I have to say is: Scoreboard?     >We have state governments, with 23 controlled by Democrats.    This one I have no argument against. Fundamentally the federalist system absolutely empowers the governors in a way analogous to the president, the state executives differ from the federal mostly in size, but there is nothing sworn to the US that isn't first sworn to a state. In many very real ways the governors/states have more power over an individual's life than the federal government could dream of. People often feel a stronger connection to their governor than their president. The prohibition on a standing military would last mere minutes if states went into open revolt.     >This is not Hungary or Turkey or Iraq — our democracy has deep roots that go back 250 years.     The age of the system is less than irrelevant when it's failing with the exact same symptoms that every failed democracy has exhibited.
Author: Aacron
